turn.text: The only thing that can't happen on remand... I want to make sure this is clear... is that the judge can't exclude on the same basis that caused the problem the first time; that is, well, it is not Reddick; it's excluded.
Not Reddick, it's excluded.
Any other factors would be open.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Egan.

turn.speaker: dennis_e_egan
turn.label: Mr. Dennis E. Egan
turn.text: Thank you.

section.heading: Rebuttal of Paul W. Cane, Jr.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Cane, you have five minutes.

turn.speaker: paul_w_cane_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul W. Cane, Jr.
turn.text: Let me begin by addressing Justice Kennedy's question about the Rule 403 issue.
I think there are two reasons why no remand is necessary.
The first, as Justice Scalia said, is that you assume that the order is correct.
You don't assume that it's incorrect.
The second--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But the... how can we make that assumption when the Tenth Circuit says we know why this district judge ruled as he or she did?
We had a precedent.
It... it dealt with employee discipline.
We said, categorically, it's got to be the same supervisor; otherwise it's not relevant.
The district judge was simply applying that case to this case.

turn.speaker: paul_w_cane_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul W. Cane, Jr.
turn.text: --Neither--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So it wasn't any 403 question.
It was this doesn't some in.

turn.speaker: paul_w_cane_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul W. Cane, Jr.
turn.text: --Neither that case nor this case involved any attempt to show that foundation, the linkage between these other persons, these other alleged bad actors, and the decision here.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But that's not... the point is that the Tenth Circuit said this judge made an absolute rule: It doesn't come in.
We know why he made an absolute rule; that was our precedent.

turn.speaker: paul_w_cane_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul W. Cane, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think the Tenth Circuit... it... it applied the incorrect presumption.
It should have applied the presumption that an evidentiary ruling is correct rather than incorrect.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: How could ut have been?
What about the date problem he just mentioned?

You said... your opponent said that when you filed this motion in limine on December 15, 2004, by that time, there hadn't been any fact-specific things at all brought up in the trial that were relevant to this, and there's certainly none in the notion that I could see.

turn.speaker: paul_w_cane_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul W. Cane, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that always will be true in the case of a motion in limine.
But the motion in limine anticipated the specific evidence that had emerged in discovery--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But where does it say?

I can't find in the motion, although there is something on disparate impact, anything that says well, you see, I don't know about the general mine run of cases, but in this particular case, it's not sufficiently material, it is a waste... it's not... it is a waste of time.
Now, I just can't find that.

turn.speaker: paul_w_cane_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul W. Cane, Jr.
turn.text: --I don't think district judges can be expected to, you know, write opinions that are... to be affirmed to be worthy of publication in F. Supp. 2d.
I think the district court considers the evidence thrown at him or her, and in this case all--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Did anyone argue that before December 15, 2004, that we don't know about the mine run of cases, but this case, in fact it's a waste of time?
Did anyone argue that before December 15, 2004?

turn.speaker: paul_w_cane_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul W. Cane, Jr.
turn.text: --That's the time when--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I'm asking yes or no; did they or didn't they?

turn.speaker: paul_w_cane_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul W. Cane, Jr.
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: paul_w_cane_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul W. Cane, Jr.
turn.text: Because that's when the court considered notions in limine.
The court was not setting standards in anticipation of a trial until the trial.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You said there were two points about 403.

turn.speaker: paul_w_cane_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul W. Cane, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, the second is I agree with Justice Alito's observation, or I think it was his observation, that it would have been abuse... an of discretion to admit this evidence anyway; and so that gets you easily by the 403 issue.

I don't think you need... there's a lot of court of appeals cases that say that where 403 factors are obvious, where they're implicit, there's not any obligation on the court of appeals' part... or on the district court's part... to... to set them forth and explicitly engage in rebalancing.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Do you not think that there is an important value that the Tenth Circuit recognized in making it clear that there is no absolute bar?

If we just assume in favor of the district court, when we don't know that the district court didn't take it as an absolute rule, that... this is a point of law that should be clarified for the benefit of district courts.
Either there's a categorical bar or there's not.

turn.speaker: paul_w_cane_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul W. Cane, Jr.
turn.text: I think that, absent some showing of relationship of nexus, then the presumptive rule in the run of cases should be that this evidence should not be admitted.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You... you don't want that clarification to be done at the expense your client, I take it?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: paul_w_cane_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul W. Cane, Jr.
turn.text: Of course not.
Let me respond to a couple of the Solicitor General's points.
The Solicitor General in his brief said three things with which we agree: the plaintiff's burden to lay foundation; anecdotes don't comprise--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: The... the Government said it was not necessary to lay a foundation.
Mr. Garre confirmed that point.

turn.speaker: paul_w_cane_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul W. Cane, Jr.
turn.text: --He did say that, Justice Ginsburg, but that's not what their brief says.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Cane.
The case is submitted.
